questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the dermatologist with multiple small, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules with a central dimple on the trunk.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phloxine Tartrate:

  • Phloxine Tartrate stain is used for identifying Henderson Patterson bodies in skin scrapings from lesions of molluscum contagiosum. This is a key diagnostic feature of the virus, distinguishing it from other infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gram stain:

  • Gram stain is used for identifying bacteria, not viral infections like molluscum contagiosum.

Option C - Ziehl-Neelsen stain:

  • Ziehl-Neelsen stain is used for detecting acid-fast bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Option D - Giemsa stain :

  • Giemsa stain is used for detecting parasites and certain bacteria, such as those causing malaria or bacterial infections, not for diagnosing molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: The most common site of Ca prostate ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Peripheral Zone:

  • The peripheral zone is the most common site for prostate cancer, accounting for about 75% of cases. It is located at the back of the prostate, making it easily palpable on digital rectal exams and often associated with detectable lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central Zone:

  • The central zone accounts for about 10% of prostate cancer cases. It surrounds the ejaculatory ducts and is the least commonly affected zone by cancer, making it a less likely site compared to the peripheral and transitional zones.

Option C - Transitional Zone:

  • The transitional zone is responsible for about 15% of prostate cancer cases. It surrounds the urethra and is commonly involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia, but it is less commonly affected by cancer compared to the peripheral zone.

Option D - Anterior Fibromuscular Stroma:

  • The anterior fibromuscular stroma does not contain glandular tissue and is rarely involved in prostate cancer. It mainly consists of smooth muscle and connective tissue, making it an unlikely site for cancer development.

questions.text: The given inheritance mode is seen in ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Incontinentia Pigmenti:

  • This X-linked dominant condition primarily affects females and is often lethal in males.
  • Affected males do not transmit the disease to their sons but transmit it to all of their daughters.
  • Affected females can transmit the disease to both sons and daughters, with each child having a 50% chance of being affected.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome:

  • This is an X-linked recessive disorder predominantly affecting males, characterized by hyperuricemia, gout, kidney problems, and self-mutilating behavior, none of which align with the clinical features described in the question.

Option C - Friedreich's Ataxia:

  • An autosomal recessive disorder causing progressive ataxia, heart disease, and skeletal abnormalities, without the distinctive skin and mucosal changes seen in the described patient, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

Option D - Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome:

  • An autosomal dominant disorder associated with multiple tumors, including retinal angiomas and renal cell carcinoma, but lacks the characteristic skin, dental, and eye findings observed in the patient, ruling it out as the correct answer.

questions.text: What type of suture is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Subcuticular Suture:

  • The subcuticular suture technique involves placing stitches just beneath the skin surface, making it ideal for closing skin lacerations with minimal scarring. This technique helps to achieve a clean and aesthetically pleasing closure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Purse String Suture:

  • This technique involves a stitch placed in a circular manner around an opening, such as for closing the end of a tubular structure.

Option B - Mattress Sutures:

  • Mattress sutures are used to approximate tissue edges and are especially effective for providing strong support and reducing tension.

Option D - Continuous Sutures:

  • Continuous sutures involve a single, unbroken stitch that runs along the length of the wound.

questions.text: What is the first sign that will be noticed on barium enema in a patient with ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mucosal granularity:

  • The given image shows a smooth colon with no haustrations – known as lead pipe colon. It is seen in Ulcerative colitis. First sign of Ulcerative colitis in barium enema – mucosal granularity

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cobble stone appearance: It is more commonly associated with Crohn’s disease, not ulcerative colitis.

​

Option C - Comb sign: It is more commonly associated with Crohn’s disease, not ulcerative colitis.

​

Option D - Saw tooth appearance: It is seen in diverticulosis, not ulcerative colitis.

​

questions.text: Which among the following Histamine receptors produce a Triple response of allergy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - H1 receptor:

  • H1 receptor
    • It is Gq type of GPCR
    • Activates phospholipase C which increases the levels of secondary messengers called IP /DAG.
    • It causes responses in two locations : CNS (Neurons) and Periphery (Mast cells/basophils)
    • Intradermal histamine produces triple response:- Redness → Wheal → Fare.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - H2 receptor:

  • Location: Stomach.
  • Gs type of GPCR → Activates adrenal cyclase → ↑ cAMP → ↑↑ HCl (Acid production)

Option B - H3 receptor:

  • Presynaptic auto receptor
  • Gi type of GPCR
  • Function: Inhibits own histamine release.

Option D - H4 receptor:

  • Gi type of GPCR
  • Present on WBC → Responsible for chemotaxis

questions.text: The given uterine condition is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Placenta abruption:

  • This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, which can result in bleeding and a Couvelaire uterus, where blood accumulates between the uterine wall and the placenta. Couvelaire uterus is directly associated with placenta abruption.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vasa previa:

  • This condition involves the presence of fetal blood vessels crossing the cervical os, which can lead to fetal bleeding during labor. However, vasa previa is not typically associated with Couvelaire uterus. Couvelaire uterus is more related to severe placental complications.

Option B - Placenta previa:

  • This is a condition where the placenta is abnormally positioned over the cervical os, causing bleeding during pregnancy. While placenta previa can cause significant bleeding, it does not lead to Couvelaire uterus.

Option D - Uterine inversion:

  • This is a rare obstetric emergency where the uterus turns inside out, usually after delivery. It is not associated with Couvelaire uterus, which is linked to placental complications rather than uterine inversion.

questions.text: Which of the following maneuvers is being demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit Technique:

  • The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique is used during breech deliveries to deliver the fetal head. The baby's body rests on the obstetrician's forearm, with fingers applied to the maxilla to flex the head, while the other hand applies suprapubic pressure. This technique provides controlled delivery of the fetal head, aligning with the procedure shown in the image.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Burns - Marshall maneuver:

Option B - Lovset Maneuver:

  • The Lovset maneuver is employed during breech delivery to deliver the fetal arms when they are extended above the head.

Option C - Pinard Maneuver:

  • The Pinard maneuver is used in breech deliveries to deliver the legs of the fetus when they are extended or impacted.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and was brought to the emergency department by bystanders. The patient was oriented and conscious and reported severe pain and swelling in the knee. On Xray, the following fracture is noted:

What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option – A ORIF:

  • The image shows a displaced fracture of tibial condyle ( type 6 plateau fracture).
  • Swelling is due to hemarthrosis and treatment of choice in a displaced fracture is Open reduction and internal fixation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Total contact cast:

  • Casting can be done as a preliminary treatment but not treatment of choice.

Option C - Total knee replacement:

  • As the femoral condyles are present and viable a total knee replacement would not be required

Option D - LING procedure:

  • This is done during the treatment of torticollis of the neck and is unrelated to the tibial fracture.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a 4 cm mass in the right breast. A biopsy reveals densely packed cells with bland nuclei and mucin infiltrating the stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option - D : Colloid carcinoma

  • Colloid carcinoma, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is characterized by clusters of bland cells floating in pools of extracellular mucin within the stroma. The presence of densely packed cells with bland nuclei and mucin infiltrating the stroma fits the description of colloid carcinoma, making this the most likely diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option - A : Invasive papillary carcinoma

  • Invasive papillary carcinoma is characterized by frond-like papillary structures, often with central fibrovascular cores. This type does not typically show dense mucin infiltration within the stroma, making it less likely given the biopsy description.

Option - B : Medullary carcinoma

  • Medullary carcinoma usually presents with large, high-grade pleomorphic cells, prominent lymphocytic infiltration, and lacks mucin production. It does not match the biopsy findings of bland nuclei and mucin infiltrating the stroma.

Option - C : Apocrine carcinoma

  • Apocrine carcinoma is distinguished by large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and a lack of mucin production. The described biopsy findings do not fit this type of carcinoma, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with the given condition What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Topical retinoids with topical antibiotics:

The patient's clinical presentation suggests grade 2 acne, which is characterized by multiple closed comedones and a few inflammatory papules. Given this grade, the most appropriate treatment involves a combination of topical retinoids and topical antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not the appropriate management of grade 2 acne.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a measure of primordial prevention in myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Screening for hypertension:

Screening for hypertension is not part of primordial prevention; instead, it is a secondary preventive measure. Secondary prevention aims to identify and manage existing risk factors early, preventing the progression of disease. This measure is used after risk factors have developed, making it a step beyond primordial prevention.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maintenance of normal body weight:
Maintaining a normal body weight helps prevent the development of risk factors like obesity, hypertension, and diabetes, which are associated with myocardial infarction. This approach falls under primordial prevention, which aims to prevent the development of risk factors in the first place.

Option B - Change in lifestyle:
Lifestyle changes, such as increasing physical activity, reducing alcohol consumption, and avoiding smoking, are crucial measures in primordial prevention. These changes help prevent the onset of cardiovascular risk factors, thereby reducing the risk of myocardial infarction.

Option C - Change in nutritional habits:
Improving nutritional habits, such as reducing salt intake, avoiding trans fats, and increasing the consumption of fruits and vegetables, is a key component of primordial prevention. These changes help prevent the development of risk factors like high cholesterol and hypertension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual, with no history of illness, unknowingly spreads an infectious agent within their community. Upon investigation, it is revealed that the individual developed this carrier state not directly from a primary case but through another carrier. What type of carrier best describes this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Paradoxical Carrier:
A paradoxical carrier develops from another carrier rather than directly from a primary case, making it the best fit for the scenario where an individual indirectly acquires and spreads an infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contact Carrier:

A contact carrier is an individual who acquires the infection directly from an existing case and spreads the pathogen. This type of carrier is in direct contact with the source of infection and becomes a conduit for transmission, unlike the scenario described.

Option C - Incubatory Carrier:

An incubatory carrier spreads the infection during the incubation period, before showing symptoms of the disease themselves. This type is characterized by the spread of infection prior to the onset of clinical illness, differing from the indirect acquisition described.

Option D - Convalescent Carrier:

A convalescent carrier is someone who continues to shed infectious organisms during the recovery phase of an illness. This carrier state is associated with the post-symptomatic phase, not an indirect acquisition from another carrier as in the described case.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with reduced sensations and numbness in his feet with an elevated HBA1C level of 8. Examination shows an unstable joint and the presence of loose bones in the feet. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Charcot joint:

Charcot joint, or neuropathic arthropathy, is a progressive degenerative condition that affects the joints in individuals with significant peripheral neuropathy. It is characterized by joint dislocations, fractures, and deformities. The patient's elevated HbA1c level and symptoms of reduced sensations and numbness in his feet suggest poorly controlled diabetes, which can lead to diabetic neuropathy and subsequent development of Charcot joint. The X-ray shows features such as bone fragmentation, subluxation, and deformity, consistent with Charcot joint.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Leprotic joint:

Leprosy can cause peripheral neuropathy and joint damage, but it usually presents with skin lesions and specific nerve involvement (e.g., thickened nerves). The joint changes in leprosy are more related to chronic inflammation and infection.

Option C - Syphilitic joint:

Syphilitic joint involvement (Charcot joint due to syphilis) is less common today due to effective antibiotic treatment. It presents with similar joint destruction due to neuropathy but is usually accompanied by other signs of tertiary syphilis, such as gummas and neurological signs.

Option D - Diabetic neuropathy:

Diabetic neuropathy typically refers to nerve damage that causes numbness and pain but does not directly cause joint destruction. However, the neuropathy can lead to Charcot joint if severe.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is essential for capturing these types of images?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dichroic mirror:

  • A dichroic mirror is essential in fluorescence microscopy. It reflects the excitation light towards the specimen while allowing emitted fluorescent light from the specimen to pass through to the detector, facilitating the capture of fluorescent images.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dark field condenser:

  • This component is used in dark field microscopy, which enhances the contrast of unstained, transparent specimens. It is not used in fluorescence microscopy, as it does not specifically handle fluorescent light.

Option B - Phase plate:

  • The phase plate is utilized in phase-contrast microscopy to enhance the visibility of transparent specimens without staining. It manipulates light paths to highlight differences in refractive indices but is not involved in fluorescence imaging.

Option D - Cathode ray tube:

  • Cathode ray tubes are outdated display devices that were used in old computer monitors and televisions. They are not components of microscopes and play no role in fluorescence imaging or microscopy.

questions.text: Which among the following microtubule inhibitors can cause Glove and stocking neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Paclitaxel:

  • Paclitaxel belongs to taxane group of microtubule inhibitors which works by inhibiting the depolymerization of microtubules.
  • Paclitaxel cause Glove and stocking neuropathy.
    • Contraindicated in liver disease
    • Paclitaxel is coated on drug-eluting cardiac stunts.
  • Others Taxanes drugs are
    • Docetaxel
      • Contraindicated in kidney disease
    • Cabazitaxel
      • Used in hormone resistant cancers (Breast cancer, Prostate cancer)
  • These drugs are less neurotoxic.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C: Estramustine, Eribulin, Colchicine

  • These drugs are also microtubule inhibitors.
  • Estramustine is used in the treatment of Prostate cancer.
  • Eribulin is used in the treatment of Breast cancer.
  • Colchicine is used in the treatment of Acute gout.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of the muscles highlighted in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Flexion at MCP joint:
The intrinsic muscles of the hand, specifically the lumbricals and interossei, play a key role in flexing the MCP joints. This function is essential for grip and fine motor control in hand movements.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Flexion at IP joint:
Flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joint is primarily performed by muscles like the flexor digitorum profundus and superficialis. These muscles are located in the forearm and act on the IP joints, not the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

Option B - Extension at MCP joint:
Extension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint is primarily carried out by the extensor muscles of the forearm, like the extensor digitorum. These muscles act on the MCP joint through the extensor mechanism but are not the function of the intrinsic muscles shown in the diagram.

Option D - Abduction at MCP joint:
Abduction of the fingers at the MCP joint is performed by the dorsal interossei muscles. However, if the diagram shows muscles like the lumbricals or palmar interossei, their main function is flexion at the MCP joint rather than abduction.

questions.text: The given umbilical artery doppler shows?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Reversed End Diastolic Flow:

  • This is the most concerning finding, indicating a critically high resistance in the umbilical artery, often seen in severe intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). It suggests impending fetal demise and is an indication for urgent delivery as fetal compromise is imminent.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Absent End Diastolic Flow:

  • This finding indicates a severe increase in placental resistance, which is concerning but not as critical as reversed flow. It suggests significant placental dysfunction and increased risk for adverse outcomes, often requiring close monitoring and possible intervention depending on gestational age and fetal condition.

 

Option C - Minimal End Diastolic Flow:

  • This finding suggests increased resistance but is less severe compared to absent or reversed flow. It requires close surveillance and may indicate worsening placental function, but it does not indicate immediate fetal danger like reversed flow.

Option D - Normal Flow:

  • A normal Doppler waveform in the umbilical artery shows adequate diastolic flow, indicating low placental resistance, which is expected in a healthy pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is NOT located on the floor of the fourth ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stria terminalis:
The stria terminalis is a structure associated with the limbic system and is involved in emotional processing and stress responses. It is located near the thalamus and amygdala, not the fourth ventricle.
This option is correct because the stria terminalis is not found on the floor of the fourth ventricle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vagal triangle:
The vagal triangle (also known as the triangle of vagus) is found on the floor of the fourth ventricle. It corresponds to the dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve and is involved in parasympathetic control of the heart and digestive tract.
 

Option B - Hypoglossal triangle:
The hypoglossal triangle is another important feature of the floor of the fourth ventricle. It marks the location of the hypoglossal nucleus, which controls motor function of the tongue.
 

Option C - Vestibular area:
The vestibular area, associated with the vestibular nuclei, is also located on the floor of the fourth ventricle. It is involved in balance and spatial orientation.

questions.text: Which of the following hypersensitivities can be noted in SLE?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - II, III:

  • Type II hypersensitivity involves antibody-mediated cytotoxicity against specific cell surfaces, seen in some autoimmune diseases but not predominantly in SLE. Type III hypersensitivity, involving immune complex deposition, is commonly seen in SLE.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - I, III:

  • Type I hypersensitivity involves IgE-mediated allergic reactions, which are not typically associated with SLE. Type III hypersensitivity, involving immune complex deposition, is a key mechanism in SLE, contributing to inflammation and tissue damage.

Option C - III, IV:

  • Type III hypersensitivity is prominent in SLE due to immune complex deposition in tissues, leading to inflammation. Type IV hypersensitivity involves T-cell-mediated responses, contributing to chronic inflammation, but is less prominent in SLE.

Option D - I, IV:

  • Type I hypersensitivity is IgE-mediated and not commonly associated with SLE. Type IV hypersensitivity, involving T-cell-mediated responses, plays a minor role in the chronic inflammation seen in SLE but is not a primary feature.

questions.text: Pericardial cyst
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Thymoma:

  • Thymoma is the most common anterior mediastinal mass and is the most common neoplasm of the thymus gland. Most patients are asymptomatic since the size of the tumor is small and is incidentally detected on chest X-ray.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • Pericardial cyst is the most common medial mediastinal mass.

Option B and C:

  • Bronchogenic cysts and Thyroid masses are not the most common anterior mediastinal masses.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with complaints of exercise intolerance. On auscultation, a grade III systolic murmur is heard. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on the ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Left Ventricular Hypertrophy (LVH):

LVH is indicated by significantly tall 'R' waves in leads such as V4, along with the sum of the S wave in V1 and R waves in V5/V6 exceeding normal values. Specifically, measurements such as S wave in V1 > 25mm and R wave in V5 > 20mm (total > 45mm) support LVH, explaining the murmur and exercise intolerance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Normal Tracing:

A normal ECG tracing would not account for the patient's symptoms and the presence of a systolic murmur. Normal tracings do not show significant abnormalities such as tall 'R' waves, which are indicative of left ventricular hypertrophy.

Option C - Atrial Fibrillation (AF):

AF would present with an absence of distinct P waves, irregular RR intervals, and a chaotic atrial rhythm. The presence of a normal P wave and regular RR intervals on the ECG rules out atrial fibrillation.

Option D - Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB):

LBBB typically shows a "W" pattern in lead V1 (broad S wave) and an "M" pattern in lead V6 (broad, dominant R wave). These patterns are not observed in the ECG, making LBBB an unlikely finding in this case.

questions.text: Diagnose the blood group.
questions.solution:
Correct Option - A : A positive:

  • Clotting with Anti-A and Anti-D indicates the presence of A antigens and the Rh factor, confirming the blood group as A positive.

Incorrect Options:

Option - B : B positive

  • Clotting with Anti-B and Anti-D would indicate the presence of B antigens and the Rh factor, making the blood group B positive.

Option - C : AB positive

  • Clotting with Anti-A, Anti-B, and Anti-D would indicate the presence of both A and B antigens along with the Rh factor, classifying the blood group as AB positive.

Option - D : O positive

  • O positive blood group would show no clotting with Anti-A or Anti-B but would clot with Anti-D, indicating the presence of the Rh factor only.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal infections would likely not show a positive result on a β-1,3-glucan test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mucormycosis:

Mucormycosis, caused by fungi from the order Mucorales, does not typically have β-1,3-glucan in its cell wall. Therefore, the β-1,3-glucan test is generally negative for Mucormycosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspergillus:
The β-1,3-glucan test is typically positive for Aspergillus species. Aspergillus is known to have β-1,3-glucan in its cell wall, which can be detected by this test.

Option B - Candida:
Candida species also have β-1,3-glucan in their cell walls. Therefore, the β-1,3-glucan test is usually positive for Candida infections.

Option D - Pneumocystis jiroveci:
Pneumocystis jiroveci does not contain β-1,3-glucan in its cell wall, and thus the β-1,3-glucan test is negative for this pathogen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Child-Pugh classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – GGT:

Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is an enzyme used to assess liver damage but is NOT a component of the Child-Pugh classification. The Child-Pugh score focuses on other clinical and laboratory parameters.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Ascites:

Ascites is an accumulation of fluid in the abdominal cavity and is a key component of the Child-Pugh classification. It is used to assess the severity of liver dysfunction by evaluating the presence and degree of ascites.

Option B – Encephalopathy:
Hepatic encephalopathy, a neurological complication due to liver dysfunction, is included in the Child-Pugh classification. It assesses the impact of liver disease on brain function.

Option D – Albumin:
Serum albumin level is a critical measure of liver function included in the Child-Pugh classification, as low levels indicate impaired liver synthetic function.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the DNA defect depicted in the image is incorrect?

choices.text: It is caused by UV light exposure.
The repair mechanism involves the activity of exonuclease.
A defect in the repair process can lead to Xeroderma Pigmentosum.
A defect in the repair process can lead to Cockayne syndrome.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The repair mechanism involves the activity of exonuclease:

  • The repair mechanism for UV-induced DNA damage primarily involves UV-specific endonuclease (or excinuclease), which excises the damaged nucleotide.
  • Exonucleases are involved in other DNA repair processes, such as proofreading during DNA replication.

Repair Process - Nucleotide Excision Repair:

  • Helicase is activated to break hydrogen bonds and unwind the DNA.
  • UV-specific Endonuclease or Excinuclease excises the damaged nucleotide.
  • Two nicks are created by UV-specific endonuclease.
  • DNA polymerase (epsilon or beta) substitutes a new strand.
  • Ligase joins the ends after substitution.

Incorrect Options

Options A, C and D are true statement

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents for a routine health check-up. His lab results indicate that his plasma volume is 3 liters, and his hematocrit (packed cell volume) is 40%. Based on this information, what is his estimated blood volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 5.0 liters:

  • The blood volume can be calculated using the formula: Blood Volume = Plasma Volume / (1 - Hematocrit). Substituting the values given, Blood Volume = 3 liters / (1 - 0.4) = 3 / 0.6 = 5 liters.

Incorrect Options:

A, B and D are incorrect as given above

questions.text: which of the following best describes the underlying cause of primary hyperoxaluria Type I?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Protein Targeting Defect:

Primary hyperoxaluria Type I is caused by a defect in protein targeting, specifically the mislocalization of the enzyme alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase (AGT). Instead of being targeted to the peroxisomes, AGT is incorrectly localized to the mitochondria due to the genetic mutation. This mislocalization impairs the enzyme's function, leading to the excessive oxalate production seen in primary hyperoxaluria Type I.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Protein Folding Defect:
While protein folding defects can cause various genetic disorders, primary hyperoxaluria Type I is specifically related to a different type of genetic problem involving enzyme localization, not protein misfolding.

Option B - Silent Mutation:
Since silent mutations do not typically disrupt enzyme activity, this is not the cause of primary hyperoxaluria Type I.

Option D - Acceptable Mutation:
Primary hyperoxaluria Type I involves a significant disruption in enzyme function due to improper targeting, not a minor or acceptable change. Thus, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension and hypokalaemia. A CT scan of the abdomen is performed. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Conn syndrome:

Also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, Conn syndrome is caused by excess aldosterone production, which leads to hypertension and hypokalaemia. A CT scan might reveal an adrenal adenoma or hyperplasia that is producing excess aldosterone.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pheochromocytoma: This condition is characterized by the production of catecholamines (like adrenaline), which cause hypertension. However, it typically does not result in hypokalaemia, and a CT scan usually reveals a mass in the adrenal glands, not a direct cause of hypokalaemia.

Option C - Liddle syndrome: This is a genetic condition resulting in overactivity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC), leading to hypertension and hypokalaemia. It does not typically present with a tumor on CT scans and is a result of a genetic defect rather than a mass.

Option D - Secondary hyperaldosteronism: This condition involves elevated aldosterone levels secondary to other issues such as liver cirrhosis or renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely uterine anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Arcuate Uterus:

  • The arcuate uterus is characterized by a mild indentation at the uterine fundus with a generally normal external contour. This is considered a mild congenital anomaly often associated with normal reproductive outcomes and is usually not linked to significant fertility issues, making it the most likely finding in this scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Septate Uterus:

  • The septate uterus has a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity. This anomaly is often linked with poor reproductive outcomes, including recurrent miscarriages. On HSG, it appears as a complete or partial division of the uterine cavity, without the mild indentation seen in the arcuate uterus.

Option C - Bicornuate Uterus:

  • The bicornuate uterus features a deep indentation on the external contour of the uterus, giving it a heart-shaped appearance with two distinct horns. This anomaly differs significantly from the slight indentation observed in an arcuate uterus.

Option D - Didelphys Uterus:

  • A didelphys uterus involves complete duplication of the uterine cavity, cervix, and sometimes the vagina, resulting in two separate uterine cavities. This condition appears as two distinct and separate uterine bodies on imaging, unlike the mild indentation of the arcuate uterus.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate investigation to monitor the progression of this condition sustained from an injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Electroretinogram (ERG):

  • It is a case of intraocular iron present in the eye.
  • The most common cause is chisel and hammer injury.
  • ERG is the investigation of choice for monitoring siderosis, as it measures retinal function by evaluating the amplitude of b waves. A decreased amplitude of the b wave indicates progressive retinal damage due to intraocular iron deposition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ophthalmoscopy:

  • While ophthalmoscopy can detect visible changes in the retina, iris, or lens, it does not provide functional information on retinal health. It cannot assess the extent of retinal damage or progression of siderosis.

Option C - Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • OCT provides detailed cross-sectional imaging of the retina, which can identify structural changes. However, it does not measure retinal function or detect changes in electrical activity related to siderosis.

Option D - Fluorescein Angiography:

  • This imaging test is used primarily to detect retinal or choroidal vascular abnormalities. It does not provide information on retinal function or the progression of intraocular iron toxicity, making it unsuitable for monitoring siderosis progression.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the given type of epidemic?

choices.text: Seen in Contaminated food sold over a period of time

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Multiple incubation periods:

  • Common Source Epidemics with Intermittent Exposure
  • There is no relation to the incubation period.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are true statements

questions.text: A patient presents with non-indurated chancres, and a gram staining of the lesion reveals a "school of fish" appearance on histological examination. Which of the following treatments is the most appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intramuscular ceftriaxone:

  • The clinical presentation of non-indurated chancres and the gram staining "school of fish" appearance are indicative of chancroid, which is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi. The most appropriate treatment for chancroid is intramuscular ceftriaxone. Ceftriaxone is an effective antibiotic against H. ducreyi and is the recommended first-line treatment for chancroid. Intramuscular administration ensures adequate drug levels and coverage for the infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intramuscular Benzathine penicillin G:

  • This option is incorrect because intramuscular Benzathine penicillin G is the treatment of choice for syphilis, not chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Option B - Oral doxycycline:

  • This option is incorrect because while doxycycline is effective against many bacterial infections, it is not the first-line treatment for chancroid caused by H. ducreyi. Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the preferred antibiotic for this condition.

Option C - Topical mupirocin:

  • This option is incorrect because mupirocin is not an appropriate treatment for chancroid caused by H. ducreyi. Mupirocin is commonly used to treat skin infections, such as impetigo, but it is not effective against the bacterium H. ducreyi.

questions.text: Which of the following schedules is appropriate for administering pre-exposure prophylaxis for rabies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Days 0, 7, 28:
Explanation: This is the correct schedule for pre-exposure prophylaxis for rabies. It consists of three doses given on days 0, 7, and 28, which provide sufficient immunity for those at ongoing risk of exposure, such as veterinarians and animal handlers.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are incorrect as given above

questions.text: Which of the following sequences correctly represents the various components of the communication process in a healthcare setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sender, Message, Channel, Receiver, Feedback:
This is the correct sequence. It starts with the sender who creates the message, which is then transmitted through a channel to the receiver. Feedback from the receiver completes the communication loop.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D are incorrect as given above

questions.text: Identify the type of tonsillitis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute Follicular Tonsillitis:

  • This type of tonsillitis is marked by the presence of yellowish spots or patches on the tonsils, indicating purulent material in the tonsillar follicles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute Parenchymal Tonsillitis:

Option C - Acute Superficial Tonsillitis:

Option D - Acute Membranous Tonsillitis:

questions.text: All of the following diseases are spread through the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Q fever:

Q fever is not transmitted by lice; it is primarily spread through contact with infected animals and their products.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trench fever:
Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana and is transmitted through the body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis). The bacteria enter the human bloodstream when the louse bites and defecates on the skin, leading to infection.

Option B - Pediculosis:
Pediculosis refers to the infestation of lice on the human body, scalp, or pubic area. It is directly caused by lice (Pediculus humanus capitis, Pediculus humanus corporis, or Pthirus pubis) and is not a disease spread by lice but rather an infestation by the lice themselves.

Option D - Epidemic typhus:
Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and is spread by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis). The louse becomes infected by feeding on the blood of an infected person, and transmission occurs when the infected louse feces come into contact with the skin through scratching.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with multiple small, erythematous, scaly plaques on his trunk that appeared after a recent sore throat. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Guttate psoriasis; Antibiotics:

The patient's presentation with small, erythematous, scaly plaques on the trunk is consistent with guttate psoriasis. These lesions often appear suddenly and are more common in children and young adults. The history of a recent sore throat is a classic trigger for guttate psoriasis. The treatment mainly includes antibiotics (penicillin, amoxicillin).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pityriasis Versicolor; Antifungal therapy:

Pityriasis Versicolor: Pityriasis versicolor typically presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented macules on the trunk, not small erythematous plaques

Option C - Erythema Nodosum; Topical steroids:

Erythema Nodosum: Erythema nodosum presents as painful, erythematous nodules on the anterior aspect of the shin.

Option D - Infectious Mononucleosis; Antibiotics:

Infectious Mononucleosis: Infectious mononucleosis can present with Forscheimer spots, and if the patient is given antibiotics (amoxicillin and ampicillin), a rash develops.

questions.text: The resting membrane potential of a neuron is equal to the equilibrium potential of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cl-:

  • The RMP of neuron (-70) is equal to the equilibrium potential of chloride, which is also -70.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Na+:

  • The equilibrium potential of Na+ is significantly positive (around +60 mV), which does not match the resting membrane potential of the nerve, typically around -70 mV.

Option B - K+

  • The RMP of almost all vertebrate cells is close to the equilibrium potential of K+.
  • The RMP of myocardial cells is equal to the equilibrium potential of potassium.

Option C - HCO3-

  • Bicarbonate ions are mainly involved in the body's buffering systems and acid-base balance

questions.text: Incorrect about the pigment shown.

choices.text: Can be positive for oil red O.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Seen more commonly in infants:
This option is incorrect because lipofuscin is more commonly seen in elderly individuals due to its association with aging and free radical damage. It is rarely seen in infants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Defined as yellow-brown in appearance:
This option is correct because lipofuscin, often referred to as the "wear and tear" pigment, appears yellow-brown in color. It accumulates as a sign of aging, particularly in long-lived cells such as neurons and cardiac myocytes.

Option B - Formed due to lipid peroxidation:
This option is correct because lipofuscin is formed as a result of lipid peroxidation, a process driven by free radical injury. The accumulation of lipofuscin indicates oxidative damage within the cells.

Option C - Can be positive for oil red O:
Lipofuscin is mainly composed of oxidized proteins and lipids .Can be positive for oil red O

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with intermittent claudication and complains of pain in his calf muscles while walking, which resolves with rest. On examination, his lower limb pulses are diminished. Based on Fontaine's staging, which stage best describes his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stage II:

  • This stage is divided into IIa and IIb, indicating intermittent claudication (pain on exertion, relieved by rest). This stage matches the patient's symptoms, suggesting mild to moderate ischemia affecting limb function during physical activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage I:

  • This stage is characterized by asymptomatic presentation, meaning there are no symptoms of ischemia despite reduced blood flow. This stage does not fit the patient's symptoms of pain during exertion.

Option C - Stage III:

  • This stage is marked by rest pain, which occurs due to more severe ischemia, typically at night or while lying down. The patient's symptoms are not severe enough to fit this stage since his pain only occurs during walking.

Option D - Stage IV:

  • This stage includes critical limb ischemia with ulcers, gangrene, or necrosis. It represents the most severe progression of the disease, which is not consistent with the patient's current intermittent symptoms without tissue loss.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option - D Empyema:

Empyema, characterized by pus accumulation in the pleural space, often causes unilateral pleural effusion with a biconvex shape. This typically results in blunting on one side rather than bilaterally, making it the least likely cause of bilateral costophrenic angle blunting.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Heart failure (Left Ventricular Failure): In heart failure, fluid accumulates in the pleural space due to increased hydrostatic pressure, leading to bilateral pleural effusions and subsequent blunting of the costophrenic angles.

Option B - Cirrhosis: Cirrhosis can lead to bilateral pleural effusions through mechanisms such as hypoalbuminemia and increased capillary permeability, commonly causing blunting of the costophrenic angles.

Option C - Nephrotic syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome results in hypoalbuminemia and fluid retention, leading to pleural effusions and bilateral costophrenic angle blunting.

questions.text: Drug of choice for treating the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Natamycin 5%:

  • Natamycin 5% is the first-line treatment for fungal keratitis, particularly effective against filamentous fungi. The regimen involves frequent application initially, followed by tapering based on the clinical response. This option directly addresses the causative organism in fungal keratitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Econazole 1%:

  • Econazole 1% is an alternative antifungal agent that can be used in fungal keratitis but is not the first choice.

Option C - Moxifloxacin:

  • Moxifloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used primarily for bacterial keratitis.

Option D - Doxycycline:

  • Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic with anti-collagenase properties, sometimes used adjunctively in bacterial keratitis to reduce corneal melting.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cross-sectional studies is incorrect?

choices.text: Better for descriptive than analytical purposes
Provides a snapshot of the population

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Establishes temporality:

Cross-sectional studies collect data at a single point in time, making it impossible to determine whether exposure preceded the outcome or vice versa. Therefore, they do not establish a temporal relationship between cause and effect.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Calculates the prevalence of disease:

Cross-sectional studies are commonly used to calculate the prevalence of a disease or condition within a specific population at a given time, providing information on how widespread a condition is.

Option C - Better for descriptive than analytical purposes:

Cross-sectional studies are primarily used for descriptive purposes, such as assessing the frequency of a condition in a population. They are less effective for analytical purposes, like investigating causal relationships.

Option D - Provides a snapshot of the population:

Cross-sectional studies provide a snapshot of the population at one point in time, allowing researchers to observe the current status of a disease or condition without assessing changes over time.

questions.text: The peak incidence of the condition among children, as shown in the image, is at the age of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4-10 months:

  • Peak incidence of intussusception is observed in this age range, typically between 4 to 10 months of age.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1-3 months:

  • Intussusception is less common in this age group. The peak incidence generally occurs later in infancy.

Option C - 11-18 months:

  • While intussusception can occur in this age group, it is less common compared to the 4-10 month range.

Option D - 2-4 years:

  • Intussusception is less common in this older age range compared to the peak incidence observed in younger infants.

questions.text: Which of the following patterns is most likely reflected in the flow-volume curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Obstructive airway disease:

Obstructive airway disease (Correct Answer): Obstructive airway diseases, such as COPD or asthma, are characterized by a concave expiratory phase on the flow-volume curve with a decreased peak expiratory flow rate due to airway narrowing. This is the classic finding in the patient’s scenario, fitting with the described flow-volume curve pattern.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mixed pattern airway disease: This pattern typically shows combined features of both obstructive and restrictive diseases on PFTs, such as decreased FEV1/FVC ratio (obstructive) and reduced total lung capacity (restrictive). However, the flow-volume curve does not specifically display a concave expiratory limb as seen in purely obstructive diseases.

Option B - Restrictive airway disease: In restrictive lung disease, the flow-volume curve appears narrow and tall with reduced lung volumes but a preserved or slightly increased FEV1/FVC ratio. The expiratory limb is usually linear rather than concave, differentiating it from obstructive patterns.

Option D - Central Hypoventilation syndrome: This syndrome is primarily a neurological condition characterized by impaired respiratory drive, leading to hypoventilation, especially during sleep. PFTs and flow-volume loops may be normal or nonspecific, without the distinct patterns seen in obstructive or restrictive diseases.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with repeated bleeding episodes, delayed milestones, and hypopigmentation. A peripheral smear is given. Which of the following defects is the most likely seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Defect in phagocytosis:

  • This presentation is characteristic of Chediak-Higashi syndrome, a rare genetic disorder involving a defect in phagocytosis due to impaired lysosomal trafficking. The condition manifests with recurrent infections, bleeding tendencies, delayed milestones, and hypopigmentation, as seen in the child.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Defect in selectins:

  • Selectins are molecules involved in the initial adhesion of leukocytes to the vascular endothelium during inflammation. A defect in selectins would primarily present with issues in leukocyte adhesion and migration but does not typically cause bleeding episodes, delayed milestones, or hypopigmentation, as seen in this case.

Option C - Defect in opsonization:

  • Defects in opsonization impair the immune system’s ability to mark pathogens for destruction but primarily present with recurrent infections.

Option D - Defect in integrins:

  • Integrin defects affect leukocyte adhesion and migration, primarily presenting with recurrent infections due to leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD).

questions.text: What mechanism helps maintain a lower temperature in the testes compared to the abdominal cavity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Countercurrent Exchange System:

  • This mechanism involves the exchange of heat between the testicular artery and the pampiniform venous plexus, maintaining a lower temperature in the testes compared to the abdominal cavity, which is crucial for proper sperm production.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thermogenesis:

  • Thermogenesis refers to heat production in the body but is not specific to maintaining temperature differences between body regions.

Option B - Thermoregulation:

  • While thermoregulation involves maintaining core body temperature, it doesn't describe the specific mechanism in the testes for lowering temperature.

Option D - Vasodilation:

  • Vasodilation widens blood vessels, leading to increased blood flow and heat dissipation, but it's not the primary mechanism for lowering testicular temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Cystoscopy:

  • Cystoscopy is the best diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula as it allows direct visualization of the bladder and the fistula opening. It helps in determining the exact location, size, and number of fistulas, which is crucial for surgical planning.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Intravenous Urography (IVU):

  • Intravenous Urography can be used to evaluate the urinary tract; however, it is less specific for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistulas. It may miss small or non-communicating fistulas and primarily identifies structural anomalies of the urinary tract rather than providing direct visualization.

Option C - CT Cystography:

  • CT Cystography is a good alternative imaging modality for identifying vesicovaginal fistulas, particularly when cystoscopy is inconclusive or when there is a need to evaluate the extent of the injury. However, it is less effective than cystoscopy for direct visualization.

Option D - Dye Test:

  • A Dye Test involves instilling a dye into the bladder and observing if it leaks into the vagina. While it is simple and non-invasive, it only indicates the presence of a fistula but does not provide detailed information about the location or size, making it less definitive than cystoscopy.

questions.text: All of the following pairs are correct for the arterial supply to the lower parts of internal capsule EXCEPT

choices.text: Anterior limb: Recurrent branch of anterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Correct D - Sublentiform part: Heubner's artery:

This is an incorrect pairing. The sublentiform part (which is part of the internal capsule below the lentiform nucleus) is actually supplied by the anterior choroidal artery, not Heubner's artery. Heubner's artery (recurrent branch of the anterior cerebral artery) primarily supplies the anterior limb.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C pairs are correct

questions.text: The given parasite eggs are not produced by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Schistosoma haematobium:

  • This blood fluke does not produce operculated eggs. Instead, it produces terminally spined eggs found in urine, which aligns with the absence of operculated eggs in the stool, making this the most likely cause.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paragonimus westermani:

  • This parasite, known as the lung fluke, produces operculated eggs that are commonly found in stool or sputum, making it an unlikely cause of the patient's presentation if operculated eggs are absent.

Option B - Clonorchis sinensis:

  • This liver fluke also produces operculated eggs, which are typically found in the stool. The absence of operculated eggs makes this parasite an unlikely cause.

Option D - Diphyllobothrium latum:

  • Known as the fish tapeworm, it produces operculated eggs, which can be found in the stool. The presence of such eggs would not match the patient's findings, ruling this parasite out.

questions.text: The patient presents with pain , nasal obstruction, fever, and a history of septal hematoma. Which of the following is least likely to be a complication of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Options D - Deviated Nasal Septum:

  • A deviated nasal septum is typically caused by trauma or congenital factors and is not a direct complication of a septal abscess. It does not result from the infection itself, making this the least likely complication associated with a septal abscess.
  • A septal abscess typically presents with:
  • These swellings occur on both sides of the nasal septum and are usually symmetric, causing nasal obstruction, pain, and tenderness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Saddle Nose Deformity:

  • This is a common complication of a septal abscess due to the destruction of the nasal septal cartilage, leading to a collapse of the nasal bridge and resulting in a characteristic sunken appearance.

Option B - Meningitis:

  • Septal abscess can lead to meningitis through the spread of infection from the nasal cavity to the meninges via venous channels or direct extension, making it a possible but serious complication.

Option C - Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis:

  • This can occur due to the spread of infection from the nasal area to the cavernous sinus through valveless facial veins, leading to life-threatening complications such as vision problems, headaches, and cranial nerve palsies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of severe hyponatremia. The patient's sodium levels have dropped to 122 mmol/l. what is the most appropriate course of action regarding fluid therapy for this patient?

choices.text: Administer 3% Normal Saline through a peripheral line to correct sodium levels
Administer 3% Normal Saline through central venous cannulation due to its hypertonic nature
Avoid fluid therapy entirely to prevent complications
Administer 0.9% Normal Saline through a peripheral line to gradually correct sodium levels

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Administer 3% Normal Saline through central venous cannulation due to its hypertonic nature:

  • Given the patient's severe hyponatremia (sodium levels of 122 mmol/l) and the hypertonic nature of 3% Normal Saline, central venous cannulation is necessary for the safe and controlled administration of this solution.
  • Central venous access allows for the rapid correction of sodium levels without causing peripheral complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Administer 3% Normal Saline through a peripheral line to correct sodium levels:

  • Administering 3% Normal Saline through a peripheral line is not appropriate due to its hypertonic nature. Peripheral administration of hypertonic solutions can lead to phlebitis and other complications.
  • It is not recommended to use a peripheral line for such solutions.

Option C - Avoid fluid therapy entirely to prevent complications:

  • Avoiding fluid therapy entirely is not a viable option, especially in a patient with severe hyponatremia.
  • Prompt and appropriate fluid therapy is essential to correct the electrolyte imbalance and prevent potential complications associated with hyponatremia.

Option D - Administer 0.9% Normal Saline through a peripheral line to gradually correct sodium levels:

  • Administering 0.9% Normal Saline (isotonic solution) through a peripheral line is a safer choice than hypertonic solutions like 3% Normal Saline.
  • While it may not correct sodium levels as rapidly as hypertonic solutions, it provides a safer approach, especially if central venous access is not immediately available.
  • In some cases, gradual correction is preferred to prevent complications associated with rapid sodium level changes, such as osmotic demyelination syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe ear pain and swelling of the ear pinna.What is the most common organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pseudomonas:

  • The most common cause of perichondritis, particularly following trauma or infection from the external auditory canal. It presents with severe pain, redness, and swelling of the ear pinna, with the lobule typically spared. Treatment often includes anti-pseudomonal antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Staphylococcus:

  • Although Staphylococcus can cause skin infections, it is less commonly associated with perichondritis compared to Pseudomonas.

Option C - Streptococcus:

  • This organism can cause various infections, but it is not the primary cause of perichondritis.

Option D - Aspergillus niger:

  • This is a fungal pathogen commonly associated with otomycosis rather than perichondritis. It does not typically cause the severe inflammation of the ear pinna seen in this case.

questions.text: The given instrument measures?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Air quality:

  • The given image is a globe thermometer
  • It is an Instrument to Measure Air Quality

Incorrect options:

Option A - Air velocity:

Air velocity is measured by an Anemometer

Option B - Air Humidity:

Air Humidity can be measured by Hygrometer

Air Temperature can be measured by Stevenson screen

questions.text: Which type of antibody is associated with the pattern observed in immunofluorescence microscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option- D : Antibodies against centromere

  • These antibodies specifically target the centromere, which is the central part of the chromosome. This is associated with the centromeric pattern in immunofluorescence microscopy.

Incorrect Options:

Option - A : Antibodies against chromatin

  • These antibodies are associated with a homogenous pattern, where the entire nucleus appears green because the antibodies target chromatin components throughout the nucleus. This is not specific to the centromeric pattern.

Option - B : Antibodies against RNA

  • These antibodies are associated with a nucleolar pattern, where the staining is observed in the nucleoli of the nucleus. This pattern does not correspond to the centromeric pattern.

Option - C : Antibodies against anti-dsDNA

  • These antibodies are associated with a peripheral or rim pattern, where enhancement is seen at the edges of the nucleus. This pattern is not related to the centromeric pattern.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia.

Laparoscopic examination findings are given below. which of the following factors is most likely associated with the development of her condition?

choices.text: Retrograde Menstruation with Decreased NK Cell Activity
Normal Estrogen Levels with Effective Immune Response

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Retrograde Menstruation with Decreased NK Cell Activity:

  • Explanation: According to Sampson’s Implantation Theory, retrograde menstruation occurs when menstrual blood flows backward through the fallopian tubes into the pelvic cavity. Although 70-90% of women experience retrograde menstruation, only about 10% develop endometriosis, largely due to decreased immune response, particularly reduced natural killer (NK) cell activity and macrophage function.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Retrograde Menstruation Alone:

  • Retrograde menstruation is common, occurring in most women. However, this factor alone is not sufficient to cause endometriosis. It requires other contributing factors, such as immune dysfunction or hormonal imbalances, to lead to the implantation and growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus.

Option C - Normal Estrogen Levels with Effective Immune Response

  • Explanation: Normal estrogen levels and an effective immune response do not predispose to endometriosis. The condition often involves increased estrogenicity, which promotes the growth of ectopic endometrial tissue, and decreased immune surveillance, which fails to clear the misplaced endometrial cells.

Option D - Increased Estrogenicity and Immune Competence:

  • Explanation: Although increased estrogen levels are associated with the growth of endometriotic lesions, a competent immune system typically manages retrograde menstruation without leading to endometriosis. The condition commonly develops when both increased estrogenicity and reduced immune function coexist.

questions.text: For which condition is the Alvarado Score primarily used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute Appendicitis:

  • The Alvarado Score is specifically designed to assess the likelihood of acute appendicitis. It includes clinical findings such as right lower quadrant pain, fever, elevated white blood cell count, and other symptoms to guide diagnosis and management decisions.

Incorrect Options B - Cholecystitis:

  • Cholecystitis involves inflammation of the gallbladder and presents with right upper quadrant pain, often associated with gallstones. The Alvarado Score is not used for this condition, as its criteria do not match the typical presentation of cholecystitis.

Option C - Pancreatitis:

  • Pancreatitis involves inflammation of the pancreas and typically presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back. Scoring systems such as the Ranson Criteria or BISAP score are used for pancreatitis, not the Alvarado Score.

Option D - Diverticulitis:

  • Diverticulitis presents with left lower quadrant pain and is related to inflammation of the diverticula in the colon. The Alvarado Score is not applicable here, as it is specific to conditions affecting the right lower quadrant, primarily acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 4 cm calculus in the left kidney, which was detected on a recent CT scan. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) :

  • PCNL is the preferred treatment for large renal calculi, especially staghorn stones, as it allows direct access to the kidney to fragment and remove the stone. It is highly effective for stones >2 cm, including complex staghorn calculi, with a high success rate for complete stone clearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)

  • ESWL uses sound waves to break stones into smaller fragments. However, it is generally not recommended for large stones like staghorn calculi (>2 cm), as it may not be effective in completely fragmenting and clearing large, complex stones, and can result in residual fragments and the need for multiple sessions.

Option C - Intrarenal Repair Surgery

  • Intrarenal surgery, such as open or laparoscopic nephrolithotomy, may be considered for very complex stones or when less invasive procedures fail. However, it is more invasive, has a longer recovery time, and has a higher complication risk compared to PCNL. It is typically reserved for cases where PCNL is not feasible.

Option D - Open Pyelolithotomy

  • Open pyelolithotomy involves the surgical removal of stones through an incision in the kidney. This approach is rarely used in modern practice due to the advent of minimally invasive techniques like PCNL and is generally reserved for very complex cases or when minimally invasive options are not available or successful.

questions.text: A newborn presents with congestive heart failure and hydrocephalus. Transcranial ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic midline mass with doppler findings as shown. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vein of Galen malformation:
Vein of Galen malformation is an arteriovenous malformation that can present in neonates with congestive heart failure, hydrocephalus, and a midline hypoechoic mass with characteristic vascular findings on Doppler imaging.

Option A – Medulloblastoma:
Medulloblastoma typically does not present with vascular abnormalities, as seen in the Doppler ultrasound, or features like congestive heart failure and enlarged optic chiasm. Therefore, this is not the most likely diagnosis.

Option B – Ependymoma:
Ependymomas typically do not cause congestive heart failure or show vascular abnormalities on Doppler ultrasound, as described in this case. Therefore, this diagnosis is less likely.

Option C – Encephalocele:
Encephalocele i does not typically present with congestive heart failure or the vascular abnormalities seen in this case, making this diagnosis less probable.

questions.text:
What is the most likely explanation for his serological profile?

HBsAg- , Anti HBs + ,Anti HBc - , HBeAg -
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vaccinated for Hepatitis B:

The presence of Anti-HBs antibodies without Anti-HBc antibodies indicates immunity due to vaccination rather than past infection, as Anti-HBc is not produced during vaccination.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Past Hepatitis B Infection:

A past infection would typically show positive Anti-HBs and Anti-HBc antibodies. The absence of Anti-HBc suggests no past exposure to the virus.

Option C - Acute Hepatitis B Infection:

Acute infection would usually present with positive HBsAg, and Anti-HBc antibodies. Negative HBsAg and Anti-HBc make this unlikely.

Option D - Chronic Hepatitis B Infection:

Chronic infection is marked by persistent HBsAg and may show positive Anti-HBc. The absence of HBsAg and Anti-HBc antibodies rules out chronic infection.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a 50-year-old male with episodic hypertension, palpitations, and sweating based on a contrast-enhanced MRI showing a T2-weighted image of the abdomen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Pheochromocytoma

  • Pheochromocytomas are adrenal tumors derived from chromaffin cells and are known to secrete catecholamines. They typically present with symptoms such as episodic hypertension, palpitations, and diaphoresis. On T2-weighted MRI, pheochromocytomas commonly demonstrate an intensely hyperintense signal, resembling a light bulb sign. This is due to the high water content within the tumor.

​

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Adrenal adenoma: Adrenal adenomas are the most common benign adrenal tumors. They often appear as well-defined masses on imaging but do not typically demonstrate the "light bulb sign" on T2-weighted MRI. Adrenal adenomas are usually hypointense on T2-weighted images and exhibit enhancement on post-contrast sequences.

​

Option C - Adrenal carcinoma: Adrenal carcinoma is a rare malignant tumor of the adrenal gland. It can present with local invasion, distant metastases, and hormonal hypersecretion. On T2-weighted MRI, adrenal carcinomas can demonstrate heterogeneous signal intensity.

Option D - Metastatic adrenal lesion: Metastatic lesions involving the adrenal glands can arise from primary cancers elsewhere in the body. They can manifest as single or multiple lesions within the adrenal glands. The appearance of metastatic adrenal lesions on T2-weighted MRI is variable and depends on the primary tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following marked areas represents the usual time of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - D: The area marked as “D” represents the usual time of diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A: The area marked as "A” represents the time of exposure.

Option B - B: The area marked as "B” represents the time of pathological changes.

Option C - C: The area marked as "C” represents the time of onset of symptoms.

questions.text: Type 3 Thyroplasty refers to which of the following as is done in case of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Shortening of vocal cords – puberphonia:

  • Type 3 thyroplasty involves shortening and relaxation of the vocal cords, which helps lower the pitch, making it ideal for puberphonia, a condition characterized by a persistently high-pitched voice in males post-puberty.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lateralization of vocal cords – puberphonia:

  • Lateralization thyroplasty is not typically used for puberphonia.

Option C - Lengthening of vocal cords – androphonia:

  • Lengthening of the vocal cords raises pitch and is used in conditions like androphonia (deep voice in females).

Option D - Medialization of vocal cords – androphonia:

  • Medialization thyroplasty moves the vocal cords closer to the midline to improve voice strength and quality, typically used in unilateral vocal cord paralysis, not for pitch modification associated with puberphonia.

questions.text: The given milestone is achieved normally at?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 6 months:

At 12 weeks, The infant bears his/her weight on the forearm with a shoulder lifted off the couch.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A,B and D as given above

questions.text: A 30-year-old diabetic man with a history of vitiligo presents with a new patch of totally depigmented skin on his leg, which developed after an injury. What phenomenon does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Koebner's phenomenon:

A 30-year-old diabetic man develops totally depigmented skin along the scar from an injury. This new depigmented area (vitiligo), which appears along the lines of trauma or scar, is a classic example of Koebner's phenomenon. The patient is advised to avoid traumas since trauma leads to Koebner's phenomenon, which in turn aggravates vitiligo.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nikolsky's sign:

This is a clinical sign where if a shearing force is applied to the skin surrounding a vesicle or bulla, it can lead to erosion or bulla. It is seen in the pemphigus group of disorders and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

Option C - Darier's sign:

This sign is characterized by the formation of erythematous wheal after the skin is stroked with a pen or key. It is commonly associated with urticaria pigmentosa.

Option D - Fitzpatrick sign:

Also known as the "dimple sign," it is observed when lateral pressure is applied to the skin over a dermatofibroma, causing a central dimple.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is commonly associated with automatism when used in conjunction with barbiturates and benzodiazepines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Alcohol:

  • Automatism, which refers to automatic or involuntary behaviors, is commonly associated with alcohol use when combined with barbiturates and benzodiazepines. Alcohol potentiates the sedative effects of these drugs, leading to increased central nervous system depression and impairments in cognitive and motor functions. This combination can result in behaviors such as sleepwalking, confusion, and loss of inhibitions, contributing to the occurrence of automatism.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nicotine:

  • Psychoactive substance found in tobacco.
  • Not typically associated with automatism when used with barbiturates and benzodiazepines.

Option B - Caffeine:

  • Stimulant found in coffee and tea.
  • Counteracts sedative effects of barbiturates and benzodiazepines.
  • Not associated with automatism when used with these drugs.

Option D - Cannabis:

  • Psychoactive substance, can have sedative effects.
  • Not commonly associated with automatism when used with barbiturates and benzodiazepines.

questions.text: The following audiogram is characteristic of ______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Menier’s disease:

  • Menier’s disease is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and an up-sloping graph, i.e., hearing loss at the low frequency of sounds.

Incorrect Options:

Option D - Noise-induced hearing loss:

  • The audiogram is of the right side ear with sensorineural hearing loss characterized by an acoustic dip, aka boiler’s notch, i.e., dip at 4 KHz for both air conduction and bone conduction is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss.

Option A - Otosclerosis:

  • Otosclerosis is characterized by a Carhartt notch, i.e., dip at 2 KHz in bone conduction and abnormal air conduction.

Option C – Presbycusis:

  • Presbycusis is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and a downsloping graph, i.e., hearing loss at high frequency.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate incision for an autopsy where the deceased is a suspected victim of asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Modified Y-Shaped Incision:
This is the correct choice in cases of asphyxia. It is a variation of the Y-shaped incision, providing enhanced access to the neck and thoracic regions, crucial for examining structures that could indicate asphyxiation, such as the trachea and esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - I-Shaped Incision:
This incision is the most commonly used during routine autopsies. It is a straight incision down the midline of the body, typically used when no specific conditions or circumstances dictate a more specialized approach.

Option B - Y-Shaped Incision:
This incision, often used in females for cosmetic purposes, starts at both shoulders and meets at the midline just above the pubic area.

Option D - X-Shaped Incision:
This incision is used primarily in custodial deaths and involves cutting from the shoulders to the opposite iliac crests. It is not done commonly.

questions.text: The contamination caused by the given weed can be tested by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nitric acid test:

The nitric acid test is used to detect Argemone oil contamination in mustard oil. When mustard oil contaminated with Argemone oil is mixed with nitric acid, it produces a reddish-brown color due to the presence of toxic alkaloids like sanguinarine, which are present in Argemone oil.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Phosphorus test:
This test is used to detect the presence of phosphorus-containing compounds. It is not specific to Argemone oil contamination and is not used for testing adulteration in mustard oil.

Option C - Coliform test:
This test detects bacterial contamination, particularly coliform bacteria, in water and food samples. It is not applicable for detecting Argemone oil contamination in mustard oil.

Option D - Methylene blue test:
The methylene blue test is used to assess the quality of milk by checking bacterial activity; it is unrelated to testing for Argemone oil contamination in mustard oil.

questions.text: An African man presents with the given skin condition.He is from a region known for river blindness. What is the most likely causative agent of his skin condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Onchocerca volvulus:

  • Onchocerca volvulus, the causative agent of onchocerciasis (river blindness), can cause skin changes such as depigmentation, known as "leopard skin." These skin manifestations result from chronic inflammation caused by the parasite's microfilariae, leading to fibrosis and pigmentation changes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Leishmania donovani:

  • Leishmania donovani causes visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) characterized by fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia.

Option C - Wuchereria bancrofti:

  • Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis, which leads to lymphedema and elephantiasis.

Option D - Strongyloides stercoralis:

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is responsible for strongyloidiasis, primarily causing gastrointestinal symptoms, skin rash, and autoinfection cycles.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Positive for Plasmodium falciparum:

  • The presence of both the Pan malaria line and the P. falciparum line indicates an infection with Plasmodium falciparum. This could also represent a mixed infection, but the presence of the P. falciparum line confirms the presence of P. falciparum.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Positive for Plasmodium vivax:

  • The Pan malaria line detects all types of malaria, but the presence of the P. falciparum line specifically indicates Plasmodium falciparum, not Plasmodium vivax. The test does not differentiate P. vivax without a specific line for it.

Option C - Positive for non-falciparum malaria:

  • Although the Pan malaria line suggests malaria infection, the additional P. falciparum line specifically confirms the presence of P. falciparum

Option D - Invalid:

  • An invalid test would lack the control line. Since the control line is present, this indicates the test is valid

questions.text: Which cranial nerve is primarily responsible for transmitting hot and spicy sensations from inner mouth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Trigeminal nerve:

  • Hot and spicy sensations are carried by the trigeminal nerve by TRV1 ion channels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Facial nerve:

  • The chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve, is responsible for transmitting taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and is not associated with hot and spicy sensations.

Option B - Glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue and is not associated with hot and spicy sensations.

Option D - Vagus nerve:

  • The vagus nerve is not responsible for transmitting hot and spicy sensations

questions.text: The prevalence of Hypertension in a community has recently decreased from 90% to 60%. Which of the following statements regarding the screening test is most accurate?

choices.text: The positive predictive value (PPV) of the test is decreased
The negative predictive value (NPV) of the test is decreased.
The positive predictive value (PPV) and NPV of the test have increased
The test's sensitivity and specificity are both affected

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The PPV of the test is decreased:

  • Higher Prevalence = Higher Positive Predictive Value (PPV): When a disease is more prevalent in a population, the probability of a positive test result correctly indicating the presence of the disease (true positive) increases. This is because there are more true positives relative to false positives in a high-prevalence setting.
  • Less False Positives = Increased Specificity: Specificity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives).
